abstract.text: A view that displays one or more lines of informational text.

inlineContent.text: You can configure the overall appearance of a label’s text, and use attributed strings to customize the appearance of substrings within the text. Add and customize labels in your interface programmatically, or with the Attributes inspector in Interface Builder.
Follow these steps to add a label to your interface:
Supply either a string or an attributed string that represents the content.
If you’re using a nonattributed string, configure the appearance of the label.
Set up Auto Layout rules to govern the size and position of the label in your interface.
Provide accessibility information and localized strings.
You provide the content for a label by assigning either a
object to the
property, or an
object to the
property. The label displays the property set most recently.
The
property allows you to control the appearance of individual characters and groups of characters, using the
API. The following image shows a label displaying an
that includes attributes to customize the font, color, and alignment of the string.
If you want to format the label’s text in a uniform fashion, set the
property to an
object containing the content, and configure the
, and
properties. The following image shows a label displaying an
with a custom font, color, and alignment.
If you set these appearance properties on a label that displays the content of the
property, the label overrides the appropriate attributes and displays the attributed string with a uniform appearance. The following image shows the label from the first image with the
property set to green.
Specify the maximum number of lines for the label to use when laying out the text with the
property. Setting a value of
allows the label to use as many lines as necessary to lay out the text within the label’s width. Use the
property to control how the label splits the text into multiple lines, and the truncation behavior associated with the final line.

Use Auto Layout to position and optionally size the label. The intrinsic content size for a label defaults to the size that displays the entirety of the content on a single line. If you provide Auto Layout constraints that define the width of the label but not the height, the label’s intrinsic content size adjusts the height to display the text completely.
When the label has its size completely defined externally, you can specify how it handles the situation when its content doesn’t fit within the bounds. To reduce the font size, set the
property to
and set the
property to a value between
and
. The latter of these properties represents how much smaller than the requested font size the label scales the text. Setting the
property to
instructs the label to reduce the spacing between characters before truncating the string. The following image shows a label that uses
and
to display the content of an entire string that would otherwise have overflowed.

content.text: Design labels for a wide audience

inlineContent.text: Labels provide valuable information to your users. To make sure that information reaches a wide audience, internationalize text and support accessibility in your labels. For information about how to implement internationalization and localization, see
. Labels are accessible to VoiceOver by default. The default accessibility traits for a label are Static Text and User Interaction Enabled. For more information, see
. To learn about using text styles to support Dynamic Type, see
For design guidance, see

abstract.text: A string of text that manages data, layout, and stylistic information for ranges of characters to support rendering.
A static, plain-text Unicode string object which you use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
A true value.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
Constants that specify text alignment.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the
API.
A collection of methods that give controls an easy way to adopt automatic adjustment to content category changes.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
A view that displays one or more lines of informational text.
A Boolean value that determines whether subviews are confined to the bounds of the view.
A Boolean value that determines whether the label reduces the text’s font size to fit the title string into the label’s bounding rectangle.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the label adjusts spacing between letters to fit the string within the label’s bounds rectangle.
A Boolean value that determines whether the label tightens text before truncating.
The styled text that the label displays.
An option that controls whether the text’s baseline remains fixed when text needs to shrink to fit in the label.
Draws the label’s text, or its shadow, in the specified rectangle.
A Boolean value that determines whether the label scrolls its text while one of its containing views has focus.
The font of the text.
The highlight color for the label’s text.
A Boolean value that determines whether the label draws its text in an enabled state.
A Boolean value that determines whether the label draws its text with a highlight.
A Boolean value that determines whether the system ignores and removes user events for this label from the event queue.
The technique for wrapping and truncating the label’s text.
The strategy that the system uses to break lines when laying out multiple lines of text.
The size of the smallest permissible font when drawing the label’s text.
The minimum scale factor for the label’s text.
The maximum number of lines for rendering text.
The preferred maximum width, in points, for a multiline label.
The shadow color of the text.
The shadow offset, in points, for the text.
A Boolean value that determines whether the full text of the label displays when the pointer hovers over the truncated text.
The text that the label displays.
The technique for aligning the text.
The color of the text.
Returns the drawing rectangle for the label’s text.
Methods that provide details about how to display your custom content in the large content viewer.
The typographic bounds-sizing behavior to handle text with fonts that contain oversize characters.
The typographic bounds-sizing behavior that handles text with fonts that contain oversize characters.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
An object that displays an editable text area in your interface.
A scrollable, multiline text region.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
Add a custom font to your app and use it in your app’s interface.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Adding a Custom Font to Your App

abstract.text: Extend the standard drag and drop support for text views to include custom types of content.
Scale text in your interface automatically using Dynamic Type.
Add VoiceOver support to make your iOS app more accessible to users who are blind or have low vision.
Methods your app can implement to respond to layer-related events.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.

media-2759882.alt: A screenshot of a label showing text aligned to the left and formatted with different attributes. The first attribute changes the text color of the second word to a color different from the rest of the text. The second attribute applies a bold font to the fifth word. The third and final attribute highlights the last four words that the label displays. The display text ends with an ellipsis indicating that the label truncates the full text at the end due to its line break mode.

media-2759883.alt: A screenshot of a label displaying text with a center alignment and truncated in the middle, showing the beginning and ending of the full text, separated with an ellipsis.

media-2759884.alt: A screenshot of a label showing left aligned text. The color of the text is green.

media-2759885.alt: A screenshot showing two labels containing the same text, displayed side by side. The label on the left side truncates the text at the end. The label on the right side displays the full text in an adjusted, smaller font that fits within the display area of the label.

value.text: A static, plain-text Unicode string object.
